22:06:24 From  Oktay Selcuk gl  to  Everyone:
	Considering relatively big data, what is the element limitation for a LIST? (e.g.: 1 million?)
22:06:26 From  Rodrigo Senra gl  to  Everyone:
	View Options -> Zoom ratio
22:06:34 From  Timo Huovinen gl  to  Everyone:
	Fixed link: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0636/
22:07:05 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Suruthi "while" is a looping keyword, you would use it to check if some condition is True; if it's False, a code block is executed and usually the value we're checking for is incremented in some way, such that eventually, the while condition becomes true and the loop is exited. The "for" loop is usually easier to control and more elegant than the "while" loop for data science purposes
22:07:06 From  Shilpa Tyagi gl  to  Everyone:
	Harish, there is a slider bar between the two screens shared. That would help you make the code screen bigger.

22:09:08 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Oktay There is no theoretical limit to how many values you can store in a list, the only constraints are memory and time required to add them into it. It's uncommon but not impossible to see lists with millions of values.

	@Pooja - The append function can only add one element at the end of the list. Two combine two lists, you can simply use the + operator.

22:17:01 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Robert That's a newline character. It ensures that the next print statement prints on the next line and doesn't continue on the same line from the previous print statement.

22:18:27 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Anita Yes, in Python, the "for" loop is basically the "for each" of older programming languages. You don't need another explicit counter in a "for" loop for that reason.
22:18:31 From  Rodrigo Senra gl  to  Everyone:
	Daniel: in python indentation defines the lexical scope (no begin,end no {} for lexical scope)
22:18:37 From  Lucy Edosomwan gl  to  Everyone:

22:18:44 From  [GL-TA] Ajith  to  Everyone:
	@Simon \n is used for starting a new line
22:19:20 From  [GL-TA] Prateek Dhokwal  to  Everyone:
	@Daniel - The for loop will end after iterating over all the elements. You can use a break statement if you want the loop to end after some condition is fulfilled.
22:19:22 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Daniel No, the "for" loop only works on the range specified and exits automatically

	@Nagaswara one,two,three,"value , with comma", five
22:35:44 From  James Pinkerton gl  to  Everyone:

22:36:18 From  [GL] Vishnu Subramanian  to  Everyone:
	@Mukul No, it is just a missing value for that cell. The missing value can be left as it is, or even filled or that row/column removed if required.

22:40:21 From  Timo Huovinen gl  to  Everyone:
	For those wondering, they square it to get rid of the positive or negative sign, to make the value absolute, and it just happens that squaring it works well with "bell" shaped sets of data, using abs() would work well for non bell shaped sets of data
22:40:28 From  Rodrigo Senra gl  to  Everyone:
	mu should be the population mean or the sample mean?

	x bar is sample mean

	Mu is pop mean

	in this example, mu appears to be population mean
22:41:58 From  Craig Munnik gl  to  Everyone:
	how should I interpret the actual values of the variance or standard deviation?
22:42:20 From  Animesh Bandyopadhyay gl  to  Everyone:
	for standard deviation, which is the most common use, is it 1/N or 1/N-1. I pre-course there are references to the use of N-1
22:42:28 From  Anita Albert gl  to  Everyone:
	variance is the square of all the diffs from the mean, then take the square root to get the standard deviation. Standard deviation would effectively be the same as simply find the diff from the mean - except that that number would always result in 0 so it is mathematically impossible to calc so we do the square first, then take back to square root. Am I understanding that correctly?
22:42:41 From  Timo Huovinen gl  to  Everyone:
	@Craig, I'm still learning, but I think most data sets are bell shaped and standard deviation is a "Step" to simplify the data you work with
22:43:23 From  Sarah Ford gl  to  Everyone:
	@Craig For some intuition on this, recall +/- 1.96 Std Devs from mean is about 95% of values in normal distribution
22:44:24 From  [GL-TA] Prateek Dhokwal  to  Everyone:
	@Animesh - 1/N-1 is used to calculate sample variance and 1/N is used to calculate population variance.
22:44:41 From  [GL-TA] Nikhil  to  Everyone:
	@anita Yes
22:45:04 From  Ramanan Kannan gl  to  Everyone:
	What was interpolation = 'midpoint' command in the previous example?
22:45:20 From  Glendon Brown gl  to  Hosts and panelists:
	what's the definition of an outlier in this case?
22:45:22 From  Timo Huovinen gl  to  Everyone:
	@Craig like, if you were to work with a histogram of data, you don't want to do a report on all of the data, you want to make it as small as possible but as large as necessary, standard deviation is just an amount that is standard in the industry
